column4: you can look at the return of this command sudo netstat -pant  and kill the process that you don't want or need.
if i kill them next boot they still working again
find out what package they are and uninstall them or modify boot to not start them
now i undrstand why debian is the more secure. i made nmap on my Ubuntu default on all ports from a Debian in my lan. after i done the same to Debian default. result no one port open ...
only ports I have open are the ones I created except maybe cups,  not sure what you installed or what you have running
sorry, but i don't accept that a service open ports w/o my permission. this is a very stupid policy from Ubuntu, Canonica or whaever
oh maybe your browser has more than one window open and so have some more ports open?
what application are these so called ports comming from?
would yo lke a pastebin?
sure pastebin it
but I like this format better sudo netstat -pant
http://pastebin.com/WMS3wyEX
for one thing I don't see an appache2 server so why is mysqld running?
dnsmasq  you must have installed that not that it's a bad thing
sshd  you also installed that
most are packages you installed except for cups  so you can install those on debian also not sure I see a difference
like icecast what is that?

these are services, doesn't matter some need locally. but no open ports please. if i do a nmap it is a disaster. I am lucky that my dsl router has a nice firewall. incredible if i had a direct connection with a modem for instance all the word can enter on my Ubuntu. this is *unmissable*
so if you need these services localy I guess you want a firewall.
so, you don want undestand me. even xp if an application try to go in listening mode ask you if it can or not, can you understand me??????? i believed linux was secure ...
just because it listens is not a security risk,  but I agree with llutz
the default firewall is to deny all
so, who changed he mine?
